content.content: I came across this recent tweet about Loopring’s bridges and connectors. The most interesting point was the following claim  Huge news! This way I can leave several governance assets on loopring and still be able to vote by interacting with snapshot L1?   Yes, this will be possible + the more people who want to do the same thing, the cheaper it is for each person  If this is true, this could be a much cleaner solution for Maker too, wouldn’t it? The idea being that low gas costs would lead to more governance participation. This is a nice complement to governance delegation as detailed in this topic. @krzkaczor, I know you’re an L2 expert here - do you have a clearer idea of whether this could work for Maker voting too?
content.GPT-summary: The post discusses the possibility of using Loopring's bridges and connectors for Maker's governance participation, which could lead to lower gas costs and more participation. The author asks for clarification from an L2 expert and mentions governance delegation as a complementary solution.

content.content: Definitely, in the future, governance can be moved to L2. Especially things like pooling. Dss-Gov RFC mentions this: MIP26: DssGov - Governance Contract Redesign

Nice! What surprised me is how close Loopring appears to be to making this possible. More details in their Medium article and a summary of it in the tweet below.   twitter.com    Loopring (loopringorg)  Key takeaways: - Cheap access to L1 dapps directly from L2 by using the power of zero knowledge proofs and batching - Cheap and capital efficient cross L2 ⮀ L2 transfers - Easy integration for CEXs to reduce deposit/withdrawal costs - Will be made available in May 2021  4:52 PM - 20 Apr 2021     48          7            It seems like Maker governance could use the bridge that they’ve built. And this is coming out in a month or so!

content.content: Ah if there’s already a significant amount of work that’s been done, perhaps it’s best to continue on that path. You probably have a much clearer picture of what Maker has already done to move to L2 than I do. For me, the main things that stood out were that Loopring is going to make it very easy to piggyback on their platform (of course, this implies that we need to trust that their L2 is secure) and being a zk-rollup, the security guarantees should be better than any optimistic rollup solution.
